top_categories.workout_context: Belgian Waffle Ride's 70% pavement, 30% unroad (dirt, gravel, single-track, sand, forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 120 miles.
At mile 60 of 120, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Belgian Waffle Ride's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before April.
83ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
10,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Belgian Waffle Ride, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
At Belgian Waffle Ride, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on mixed unroad and pavement. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Belgian Waffle Ride. Train it until it feels boring.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 120 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
10,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
120 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.

race_overlay.heat: April in Del Mar, California can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Belgian Waffle Ride. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Belgian Waffle Ride’s 120 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Belgian Waffle Ride demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride mixed unroad and pavement at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: 70% pavement, 30% unroad (dirt, gravel, single-track, sand, rock gardens), water crossings. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 120 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Durability, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 120 miles of mixed unroad and pavement in Del Mar, California.
